required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Shifting Salty Taste Preferences in Children
clinical_study.official_title: Salty Taste: Assessing a Strategy to Reduce Children's Preference

brief_summary.textblock: The goals of the proposed research are to determine whether repeated exposure to a low sodium food will result in reduced preference for salt in that food among children; and to determine whether such reductions in preference are related to dietary intake of salt, taste receptor genotype, and anthropometric and physiological measures.

detailed_description.textblock: This is a within- and between-subjects randomized controlled trial on children consuming either a low sodium or a higher sodium cereal over a 2-month period to determine if repeated exposure to the low sodium cereal is effective for reducing preference for salt in that food. Children will be genotyped for markers related to taste, dietary intake will be recorded, and anthropometric and physiological measures will be collected at baseline.

primary_outcome.measure: Most Preferred Level of Salt Taste
primary_outcome.description: Children were presented with pairs of broths with varying concentrations of added salt (0.16, 0.24, 0.38, 0.61, 1.05 M) (17) . The first pair of broths (0.24 and 0.61 M salt) presented were from the middle range of concentrations. Children were instructed to taste each sample within a pair for 5 seconds, to rinse between tastings, and then to point to the sample they liked better. Each subsequent pair of samples contained the concentration selected by the participant paired with an adjacent stimulus concentration. This pattern continued until the child either chose the same concentration when paired with both a lower and higher concentration in two consecutive pairs or chose either the highest or the lowest concentration twice consecutively. The entire task was repeated a, with stimulus pairs presented in reverse order. The geometric mean of the two concentrations chosen in the first and second series was calculated to determine most preferred levels of salt.

primary_outcome.measure: Relative Preference for Regular vs Low Sodium Cereal
primary_outcome.description: The number of children who preferred the taste of the low salt cereal when compared to the regular sodium cereal

secondary_outcome.description: Detection thresholds (the lowest level of salt detect by taste) were measured via a two-alternative forced-choice procedure

Children were presented with pairs of sucrose solutions of varying concentrations (0.09, 0.18, 0.35, 0.70, 1.05 M). The first pair presented were from the middle range of concentrations. Children tasted each sample and then pointed to the sample they liked better. Each subsequent pair of samples presented contained the concentration selected by the child paired with an adjacent stimulus concentration. This pattern continued until the child either chose the same concentration when paired with both a lower and higher concentration in two consecutive pairs or chose either the highest or the lowest concentration twice consecutively. The entire task was repeated after a 3-minute break, with stimulus pairs presented in reverse order. The geometric mean of the two concentrations chosen in the first and second series was calculated to determine the most preferred levels of sucrose.

secondary_outcome.measure: Intake of Cereal During Intervention Period
secondary_outcome.description: Mothers recorded the amount of cereal their children ingested during 28 days of the 8-week, at-home intervention period.

Blood pressure (mmHg) was measured by using an automatic blood pressure machine with pediatric cuff. Blood pressure will be measured at baseline (time 0). There were no a priori hypothesis but were collected as baseline characteristic to ensure no differences between the groups.

arm_group.description: Children will receive regularly salted cereal to consume 4 times per week over a 2-month period.
Intervention: Children will receive low sodium cereal to consume 4 times per week over a 2-month period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Healthy
- Willingness to consume no other cereals during intervention
Exclusion Criteria:
- Allergies and/or taking medication that affects taste

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Mothers were recruited from a list of past participants in our research program who asked to be contacted for future studies. Study was conducted at The Monell Chemical Senses Center in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania USA in 2016.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Children were randomized at the beginning of the first test session. There were no significant effects that occurred after participant enrollment but before randomization to study group.

group.title: Control Group [Regular Sodium Group]
group.description: Children will receive regularly salted cereal to consume 4 times per week over an 8-week (2-month) period.

group.title: Low Sodium Group
group.description: Intervention: Children will receive low sodium cereal to consume 4 times per week over an 8-week (2-month) period. Low Sodium Group: Breakfast Cereal

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcome.title: Most Preferred Level of Salt Taste
outcome.description: Children were presented with pairs of broths with varying concentrations of added salt (0.16, 0.24, 0.38, 0.61, 1.05 M) (17) . The first pair of broths (0.24 and 0.61 M salt) presented were from the middle range of concentrations. Children were instructed to taste each sample within a pair for 5 seconds, to rinse between tastings, and then to point to the sample they liked better. Each subsequent pair of samples contained the concentration selected by the participant paired with an adjacent stimulus concentration. This pattern continued until the child either chose the same concentration when paired with both a lower and higher concentration in two consecutive pairs or chose either the highest or the lowest concentration twice consecutively. The entire task was repeated a, with stimulus pairs presented in reverse order. The geometric mean of the two concentrations chosen in the first and second series was calculated to determine most preferred levels of salt.
outcome.population: Some children did not understand the task and responded at random.

class.title: Baseline, Number preferred low salt cereal
End Intervention, Number preferred low salt cereal

analysis.groups_desc: Yates’s chi-square analyses were used to determine which of the two cereals children in each group preferred at baseline and after the 8-week exposure period, and whether the number of children who shifted preference from the regular cereal at baseline to the low salt cereal after the exposure period differed between groups.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Yates’s chi-square analyses were used to determine which of the two cereals children in each group preferred at baseline and after the 8-week exposure period, and whether the number of children who shifted preference from the regular cereal at baseline to the low salt cereal after the exposure period differed between groups.

outcome.title: Salt Taste Detection Thresholds
outcome.description: Detection thresholds (the lowest level of salt detect by taste) were measured via a two-alternative forced-choice procedure
outcome.population: Some children did not understand or complete the task.

Each subsequent pair of samples presented contained the concentration selected by the child paired with an adjacent stimulus concentration. This pattern continued until the child either chose the same concentration when paired with both a lower and higher concentration in two consecutive pairs or chose either the highest or the lowest concentration twice consecutively. The entire task was repeated after a 3-minute break, with stimulus pairs presented in reverse order. The geometric mean of the two concentrations chosen in the first and second series was calculated to determine the most preferred levels of sucrose.

measure.title: Intake of Cereal During Intervention Period
measure.description: Mothers recorded the amount of cereal their children ingested during 28 days of the 8-week, at-home intervention period.

analysis.groups_desc: Generalized estimating equations (GEE) were conducted on the amount of cereal in grams ingested during 28 days home-exposure period. The GEE approach accounts for the repeated measurements of outcomes over time for each child and examines whether the slopes of the lines created differ between the treatment groups.

outcome.title: Blood Pressure
outcome.description: Blood pressure (mmHg) was measured by using an automatic blood pressure machine with pediatric cuff. Blood pressure will be measured at baseline (time 0). There were no a priori hypothesis but were collected as baseline characteristic to ensure no differences between the groups.

measure.title: Blood Pressure
measure.description: Blood pressure (mmHg) was measured by using an automatic blood pressure machine with pediatric cuff. Blood pressure will be measured at baseline (time 0). There were no a priori hypothesis but were collected as baseline characteristic to ensure no differences between the groups.

analysis.groups_desc: T-tests were conducted to determine whether differences in baseline blood pressure between the two groups.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: T-tests were conducted to determine whether differences in baseline blood pressure between groups

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: We did not collect reliable diet records so no data were available to report.
